questions.text: The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is _____.
questions.solution:
The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is bitemporal hemianopia.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting in the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. The clinical features of craniopharyngiomas include headaches, visual field defects, growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction. CT scan may show calcifications in the supra-sellar region. Treatment includes trans-sphenoidal resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.

Lesions of the optic chiasma can cause bitemporal hemianopia, i.e, loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level, and hence, these fibers are compromised.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma

Other options:

Option B) Binasal hemianopia is a rare visual field defect also caused due to lesions at the optic chiasma.  

Option C) Superior quadrantanopia is also known as pie-in-the-sky defect and is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.  

Option D) Inferior quadrantanopia is also known as pie-on-the-floor defect and is caused due to lesions affecting the superior fibers of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles containung Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed of Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the given image.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. 

Herpes simplex causes epithelial keratitis and in severe forms, dendritic ulcers develop. Most of the patients present with redness, photophobia, watering, and blurred vision. On examination, visual acuity and corneal sensation are reduced. Follicular conjunctivitis and blepharitis may develop but are usually mild. Clinical reactivation occurs due to multiple stress factors and causes recurrent infections.

The fluorescein-stained image under slit-lamp examination shows dendritic ulcers, a pathognomic feature of epithelial keratitis. They are mostly treated with acyclovir 3% ointment or ganciclovir 0.15% gel.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of floaters and photopsia for the past 3 months. The consultant uses the following instrument to evaluate the patient. What method is being used?
questions.solution:
The method being used is indirect ophthalmoscopy. It is a type of ophthalmoscopy and is used for fundus examination. 

Fundus examination can be done using ophthalmoscopy or a slit-lamp biomicroscopy. Ophthalmoscopy is the method of assessing the interior of the eye by using an ophthalmoscope. There are 3 types of ophthalmoscopy, mainly indirect ophthalmoscopy, direct ophthalmoscopy, and distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted, and magnified image. It is essential for assessing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. 

Advantages of  an indirect ophthalmoscope over a direct ophthalmoscope are:

Feature Indirect Ophthalmoscopy Direct Ophthalmoscopy
Image Real, Inverted Virtual, Erect
Magnification  X~2.5   X 15
Area of the field in focus  Much larger (8 disc diameter) Small (2 disc diameter)
Examination through hazy media Possible Not possible
Depth perception Possible Not possible

Other options:

Option A: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is used to scan the eye anteroposteriorly and horizontally. 

Option C: Direct ophthalmoscope is most commonly used in routine fundus examination. Its features can be seen in the table above.

Option D: Distant direct ophthalmoscopy is used to help recognize a detached retina, diagnose opacities in the refractive media, etc. It can be performed using a self-illuminated ophthalmoscope or a simple plain mirror with a hole at its center.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: During ward  rounds in Ophthalmology, there was a discussion about various modes of ultrasound scan. Which of the following is not an indication for a B mode  scan?
questions.solution:
Assessment of anterior chamber depth is done by "A" scan. The rest are all indications for a B scan. 

Both 'A' and 'B' scans are types of ultrasound (USG) scans.

It produces a unidimensional image and echoes are plotted as spikes. It produces a two-dimensional dotted section of the eyeball.

Uses:

  • Intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation: Biometry
  • Anterior chamber depth
  • The thickness of intraocular mass

Uses:

  • Localization of intraocular and intra-orbital foreign bodies

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination of the affected eye, a relative afferent pupillary defect with a normal optic disc is seen. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis:

  • papillitis
  • neuroretinitis
  • retrobulbar neuritis

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

Signs of optic neuritis:

  • Marked reduction in visual acuity
  • Impaired color vision
  • Marcus Gunn Pupil indicates the relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is a diagnostic sign. Can be detected by swinging flashlight test
  • Disc hyperemia with blurred margin
  • Central or centrocaecal scotoma in the visual field (most common field defect in optic neuritis)
Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease). 

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Capsulorrhexis is the step shown in the given image.

Capsulorrhexis is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens. It is one of the steps involved in conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE).

Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered to be superior to all the pre-existing methods because when done correctly, it does not leave any edges or tears. Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility.

In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex. This leaves the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact. The intact lens nucleus is then removed from the eye through a limbal incision. 

An anterior capsulotomy is followed by hydrodissection using a balanced salt solution. This helps to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule. Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula. An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted and the incision is then closed.

Some of the IOLs used are shown in the image below.

questions.text: A middle-imaged female patient presents to the clinic with sudden onset mild ptosis, decreased sweating on the same side, and anisocoria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient with sudden onset mild ptosis, decreased sweating on the same side and anisocoria is Horner syndrome.

Horner syndrome is also termed oculosympathetic palsy. Presentation depends on the level of lesion in the sympathetic chain.

Patients commonly present with symptoms such as

  • Mild ptosis
  • Anisocoria (difference in size of the pupils) accentuated in dim light
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating

Tests with topical apraclonidine and cocaine can be used to confirm a diagnosis of Horner syndrome.

Other options

Option A: Adie's tonic pupil is caused by damaged sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle following a viral illness. Patients present with large regular pupils that have absent/sluggish light reflexes.

Option C: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic facial palsy affecting lower motor neurons. There is an ipsilateral restriction of eye closure and facial muscle weakness.

Option D: Argyll Robertson pupil is caused by neurosyphilis. On examination, there are irregular small pupils that do not change in size in bright light. However, they constrict on accommodation.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, there is chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis.

Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit posterior to the orbital septum. If left untreated it may progress to either a subperiosteal or orbital abscess. 

Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children.

Patients present with pain, lid edema, erythema, conjunctival chemosis, and axial proptosis. Decreased ocular motility and relative afferent pupillary defect can also be seen. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve.

Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is a paradoxical response of a pupil to a light stimulus. It is tested by the swinging flashlight test.

Other options:

Option A: Optic neuritis is an inflammatory and demyelinating disorder of the optic nerve in which patients present with symptoms such as sudden monocular vision loss, impaired color vision, and impaired depth perception.

Option B: Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis present with edema in the mastoid region which is not seen in orbital cellulitis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a bilateral condition due to intercavernous communication. Patients can also present with ophthalmoplegia due to palsy of the 3rd,4th and 6th cranial nerves.

Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. Patients present with painful periorbital swelling and there is no proptosis. Ocular movements and visual acuity are normal in patients with this condition.

questions.text: Identify the condition below which presents as painless loss of vision.
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed tomato appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Treatment usually involves treating the underlying cause and complications.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the presence of posterior capsular opacification is suggestive of after-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment.

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B- Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C- Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D- Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic.

questions.text: Internal hordeolum is due to inflammation of:
questions.solution:
Internal hordeolum is due to inflammation of Meibomian gland.

Hordeolum internum is the suppurative inflammation of the Meibomian gland and may occur as a primary infection or secondary to infected chalazion. There is a tender swelling with the pus point facing toward the tarsal conjunctiva. The below image shows an internal hordeolum.

A chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen. A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

Hordeolum externum or stye is the suppurative inflammation of the gland of Zeis. It is hard and painful, and there is a visible pus point on the lid margin.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment. 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis.
  • Choroidal tumours like melanoma.
  • Toxaemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis. Clinical signs include:

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign- Subretinal fluid detaches the area of the retina under which it accumulates. In the upright position, it collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens, the fluid shifts posteriorly which detach the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots- Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD- due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region respectively.

questions.text: Cornea verticillate is caused by______.
questions.solution:
• Cornea verticillate/vortex keratopathy is a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium.
  • Causes
    • Amiodarone
    • Tamoxifen
    • Indomethacin
    • Chloroquine
    • Fabry’s disease
    • Rare cause: chlorpromazine
  • Opacity due to drugs is reversible on stopping the drug.

Image: Vortex keratopathy

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and a clear, but large, cornea as well as Haab’s striae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma.

Note: 

Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

The image given below shows Vogt's striae.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. He is diagnosed with a fungal ulcer. What of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye

questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

The image given below shows a fungal ulcer:

Treatment:

Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A worried mother brought her son for vision examination when she noticed him reading a book too closely. She says he also narrows his eyes while watching television. Examination revealed myopia. Which of the following lens should be prescribed to correct this child's vision?
questions.solution:
Concave lenses are used for correcting myopic errors.

Myopia, also known as 'short sight', is that dioptric condition of the eye in which, with the accommodation at rest, incident parallel rays come to a focus anterior to the light-sensitive layer of the retina. 

Other options:

Convex lenses are used in the correction of hypermetropic eye and presbyopic eye.

Cylindrical lenses are used in the correction of astigmatism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of constant watering of eyes with mucopurulent discharge and a non-pulsatile swelling as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of excessive watering of the eyes and swelling over the lacrimal sac in an infant is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis.

Congenital dacryocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac due to the accumulation of secretions. This occurs secondary to an obstruction along the course of the nasolacrimal duct.

Clinical features are epiphora progressing to mucopurulent discharge, positive regurgitation test, and swelling over the lacrimal sac area.

The treatment plan is decided according to the age at presentation. Massaging over the lacrimal sac and topical antibiotics are used as first-line treatment.

Management

  • Massage over the lacrimal sac area along with topical antibiotics is a conservative management method that can cure symptoms in infants up to 6-9 months
  • Probing of the nasolacrimal duct with Bowman's probe can be attempted if symptoms do not resolve within 6 months. 
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy may be done if the child is brought late or if all other treatment methods fail. 

Other options:

Option A: Anterior encephalocele is a pulsatile swelling in the superomedial part of the orbit. It is caused by the herniation of intracranial content through a congenital defect in the skull.

Option C: Syringomas are benign proliferations of eccrine sweat glands and are noted as multiple small papules. 

Option D: Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous, painless swelling of the Meibomian gland in the eyelid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

questions.text: Which of the following test is not used to assess color vision?
questions.solution:
Amsler's grid test is not used to assess color vision. It is used to assess macular pathology.

Commonly employed color vision tests include:

  • Ishihara’s chart
  • Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test
  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  • Edridge-Green lantern test
  • City University test
  • Holmgrens wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope

The below image shows the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test, which is used to test color vision. Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test is similar to the below test but it utilizes only 15 hue caps.

 

Ishihara's chart (image below):

 

Holmgrens wool test (image below):

 

Amsler grid test is used in detecting maculopathy.

Other uses include:

  • Assess macular function
  • Evaluate the visual field of 10°
  • Good for follow-up in CSR (Central serous retinopathy)

The image below shows a normal Amsler's grid.

Metamorphopsia is a condition in which patients perceive distorted images of the object, which occurs in macular pathology. The image below shows metamorphopsia seen on Amsler's grid.

questions.text: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is due to a lesion in the _______.
questions.solution:
Lesion to the medial longitudinal fasciculus causes internulcear ophthalmoplegia.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

  • Lesion to medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
  • Seen in multiple sclerosis

Anatomy

  • After initiation, horizontal eye movements are generated in the horizontal gaze centre (PPRF) and mediated via a common pathway.
  • From here, impulses travel
    • directly to the ipsilateral sixth nerve nucleus and
    • indirectly via internuclear neurons that cross the midline at the level of the pons and pass up the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), to motor neurones in the medial rectus subnucleus of the contralateral third nerve complex.
  • Stimulation of the horizontal gaze center on one side, thereby causing a conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.

Features:

  • Defect in ipsilateral adduction: Medial rectus defect
  • Horizontal diplopia
  • Nystagmus of opposite eye
  • Convergence is normal

 Image: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

questions.text: What is the use of this surgical instrument?

choices.text: Dilate the punctum of lacrimal gland
Curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora

questions.solution:
The given image shows Bowman's lacrimal probe.  It is identified by the ends of the lacrimal probe which are blunt with a central stable platform. It is used to probe the nasolacrimal duct in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is also used to identify the lacrimal sac during dacryocystorhinostomy and dacryocystectomy.

Other common instruments used in lacrimal gland surgeries:

Nettleship lacrimal punctum dilator (shown in the image attached below) is used to dilate the punctum before lacrimal sac surgeries (Option-A)

 

Lacrimal gland cannula is used for syringing the lacrimal gland and the passage. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. (Option-C)

 

Lacrimal sac curette is used to curette the lacrimal sac in cases of epiphora (Option-D). It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted.

questions.text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of oculomotor nerve palsy (3rd nerve palsy).

The central image shows the eyes in primary gaze where the patient's left eye has deviated down and out. There is also profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle. Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will be impaired. Abduction and depression in the primary position (down and out) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. All of these findings indicate left oculomotor nerve palsy.

The signs of left oculomotor nerve palsy are summarized in the image attached below. 

Other options:

In trochlear nerve palsy (4th nerve palsy), the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of the Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia.

In abducens nerve (6th nerve palsy), the lateral rectus is affected. Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of watering eyes and inability to keep eyes opened in a bright room. On ocular examination, the following finding is noted. The finding is a defect in which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with photophobia and excessive watering and image showing Haab striae is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in the descemet membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP) which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Below image shows hazy cornea.

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; IV ketamine lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: A preterm baby in the neonatal intensive care unit is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She is found to have stage 2 ROP in zone I with no plus disease.  What is the recommended treatment for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
The recommended treatment for ROP stage 2 in zone I (categorized as type I/low-risk ROP) is careful observation and follow-up.

Retinopathy of prematurity occurs in premature infants with low birth weight, with a typical history of exposure to oxygen in high concentrations leading to bilateral proliferative retinopathy. 

Stages of Retinopathy of Prematurity:

  • Stage 1- demarcation line formation at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3- ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous.
  • Stage 4- subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- total retinal detachment
  • 'Plus' disease is characterized by dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels in at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus. It signifies the progression of the disease.

Location:

Zone I: Circular area with a radius twice the distance from disc to the fovea, with the disc as the center. (as shown in the image)
Zone II: It covers the area beyond zone I circumferentially till nasal ora serrata.
Zone III: It consists of residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

These zones are shown in the image below:

 

Treatment is based on guidelines set by the early treatment of retinopathy of prematurity trial (ETROP).

Type 1: Treatment within 72 hours (High risk)

  • Any ROP + plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP in zone I
  • Stage 2/3 in zone II + plus disease.

Type 2: Observation (Low risk)

  • Stage 1/2 in zone I only and no plus disease
  • Stage 3 ROP within zone II and no plus disease.

This can be summarized in the table below:

    Stage 1   Stage 2   Stage 3
Zone I Observation Observation Treatment
Zone II - without plus disease   Observation  Observation
Zone II- with plus disease   Treatment Treatment

 

ROP of any stage in any zone, if associated with 'plus' disease, should receive treatment urgently.

Treatment includes laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina, anti-VEGF medication (bevacizumab), and pars plana vitrectomy for advanced disease. The high-risk patients requiring treatment should receive it within 72 hours.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of
questions.solution:
Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease. 

The classic feature of 'silent choroid' or ‘dark choroid’ is due to masking of background choroidal fluorescence by diffuse RPE abnormality. 

Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM) 

It constitutes the most common type of macular dystrophy. It is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin within the RPE. 

Signs

  • The macula :
    • May initially be normal ,later progressing to an oval ‘snail slime’ or ‘beaten-bronze’ appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow–white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions at the level of the RPE. 

Investigation 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid ,the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence

Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) shows hypofluorescent spots.

questions.text: A patient's eye was hit by a tennis ball and developed Hyphema. What is the likely source of bleeding ?
questions.solution:
Circulus arteriosus major is responsible for Hyphaema (blood in the anterior chamber).

Hyphaema:

Causes of Hyphaema:

  • Ocular injuries
  • Postoperative
  • Herpes zoster iritis
  • Gonococcal iritis
  • Intraocular tumor
  • Spontaneous (from rubeosis iridis)

Two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula can be used for aspirating hyphaema.

Blood Supply of Eye:

Cornea: Avascular

Uvea: 3 arteries are important.

  • Short post ciliary artery- Choroid
  • Long post ciliary artery-2 in number join each other near ciliary muscle with anterior ciliary arteries to form circulus arteriolar major (C A major).
  • Short anterior ciliary arteries join long posterior ciliary arteries to form C A major.
  • Branches from circulus arteriolar major go to the pupillary border to form circulus arteriosus minor(C A minor).

Retina:

  • Outer four layers-choriocapillaries (RPE, rods and cones, ELM, outer nuclear layer)
  • Inner layers- Central retinal artery
  • Macula- Branches of central retinal artery + Choriocapillaries.
  • Foveola- Avascular

Optic Nerve Head:

  • Surface nerve fibre layer- From retinal arteriole.
  • Lamina cribrosa- From ciliary vessels derived from posterior ciliary artery and arterial circle of Zinn and Haller.
